text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.17.2, Publishing - Publishing Systems and Programs.
1.17.2.3.6(4), Letter Program - Updated the link for the Form Letter program.
Editorial changes made to update program director title and name, punctuation and to conform to Plain Writing requirements.
This supersedes IRM 1.17.2 dated August 12, 2021.
All IRS employees, contractors, and vendors who design, publish, or distribute printed and/or electronic material.
Table of Contents
Systems and Programs
page (

) This section describes established publishing programs administered by the Publishing organization. It includes various electronic systems and and used to receive, order, control, issue and support the publication of IRS print and electronic communications products. (
) Updates to changes in services are posted on the Media & Publications Publishing and Distribution Intranet website at http://publish.no.irs.gov. (

) Product originators must request all services from M&P Publishing by ting a Publishing Services Request (PSR), regardless of the type of media ultimate production source determination. M&P Publishing assigns the PSR a publishing specialist to provide service. (

) The PSR automates the process of obtaining business and funding gathering product information, and initiating contact with Publishing. Product originators can use the PSR to request any type of publishing service that viously required a Form
, Publishing Services Requisition. (

) The requisition requires signature authority from one of the following before any resources can be committed: • The Commissioner • Operating Division Commissioners or Deputy Commissioners or their designees • Chief Officers or designees • National Taxpayer Advocate • Chief Counsel, or • Other Executive Heads of Office or designees (
) Each office must provide M&P Publishing with a list of individuals authorized sign their requisitions. Use Form
, Authorization to Designate Business Approvers for Publishing Services Requests, to add, delete, or update titles, office symbols or SEIDs. Submit a new Form
when changes occur. (
) Product originators should only use the Form
when the online PSR is available or cannot meet the customer’s requirements. (
) For additional information on how to ﬁll out a PSR, refer to IRM
, Pub- lishing, User Guide for Requesting Published Products and Services. (

) Customers needing copy services should consult with a publishing specialist submit a PSR. You can ﬁnd the list of publishing specialists on the website at http://publish.no.irs.gov/publish/psal.html. (

) This section describes programs that M&P Publishing provides: • Business Card • Employee Recognition Program for Career Service and Performance Awards • Envelope • Internal Revenue Bulletin • Internal Revenue Manual • Letter • Letterhead/Stationery (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Updates to changes in services are posted on the Media & Publications (M&P) Publishing and Distribution Intranet website at http://publish.no.irs.gov.

The PSR automates the process of obtaining business and funding approvals, gathering product information, and initiating contact with Publishing. Product originators can use the PSR to request any type of publishing service that pre- viously required a Form 1767, Publishing Services Requisition.
For additional information on how to ﬁll out a PSR, refer to IRM 1.17.9, lishing, User Guide for Requesting Published Products and Services.
This section describes programs that M&P Publishing provides:
Employee Recognition Program for Career Service and Performance Awards Envelope Internal Revenue Bulletin Internal Revenue Manual Letter Letterhead/Stationery

) For a complete and current list of Publishing programs, go to irs.gov/publish/puborg.html. (
) The IRS has the authority to pay for business cards for employees directly involved in promoting Electronic Tax Administration, personnel recruitment, Card Program signiﬁcant public contact. (
) M&P Publishing manages the production contract for business cards and has developed a system that allows employees and managers to request and business cards electronically. (
) Find up-to-date information and guidance about the business card program the M&P Publishing website at http://publish.no.irs.gov/pubsys/bcard/bcards. html#tab=tab

) The IRS designed the Employee Recognition Program (ERP) to recognize employees with various awards and/or certiﬁcates. IRS managers are Recognition aged to recognize employee contributions and accomplishments through the Service and ERP. The manager must decide what type of award or certiﬁcate is Awards for the employee to receive and must include a brief write-up, which will be formatted on the award or certiﬁcate. (
) A publishing specialist in the Functional Publishing section manages all aspects of this program, including the ordering, designing, prooﬁng, and bution of these awards to the recipients. (
) See IRM
, IRS Employee Recognition Program, for more or visit the Employee Recognition Program website at http://hco.web.irs.gov/ erp/index.html. (
) Product originators must use an approved PSR to make all requests for non- career and non-performance awards and must include Form
, Recognition Program (ERP) - Order Request Summary, and Form
-A, Employee Recognition Program (ERP) - Certiﬁcate Personalization Request. (
) All awards are personalized and sent directly to the originator or the (
) See IRM
, Employee Performance and Utilization - Awards and nition, for more information and guidance on how the Internal Revenue recognizes employees. (

) The envelope program provides all IRS offices with the correct size, type, quantity of printed envelopes required for correspondence and special Program programs and ensures that all envelopes conform to Postal Service regula- tions. (

) Envelope Program Specialists are responsible for reviewing and processing printing requisitions and/or procurements, administering the envelope contracts, updating and maintaining envelope ordering procedures, and pating on various task forces and groups responsible for the Envelope Program workﬂow processes and/or implementations.
Systems and Programs 1.17.2

, Envelopes, provides detailed information on the envelope program, including envelope standards, ordering and procurement speciﬁcations review, IRS envelope contracts, and other related information. (
) Additional envelope user information is available on the M&P Publishing Distribution website at (

, Item IDs, regarding identiﬁcation standards for envelopes. (

) The authoritative instrument for the distribution of official IRS tax guidance the Internal Revenue Bulletin (IRB), a weekly collection of items of general Revenue interest to the tax professional community. (IRB) Program (

) The IRS publishes a weekly bulletin that contains all substantive rulings necessary to promote a uniform application of the tax laws. The ﬁrst bulletin the calendar year is reserved for publication of user fees, technical advice, procedures for issuing rulings. (
) The weekly bulletin is available on the Internal Revenue Service Bulletin on the Intranet at http://core.publish.no.irs.gov/irb/pdf/index.html, and on the Internet at http://www.irs.gov/irb/. (

) The IRM is the primary, official source of IRS instructions to staff relating to administration and operation of the Service. The IRM contains policy, proce- Revenue Manual dures, and direction employees need to carry out their responsibilities in Program administering tax laws or other agency obligations. (
) Publishing specialists on the IRM team manage publishing the IRM, • Reviewing and processing Form

, Publishing Service Requisition • Administering the IRM composition and printing contract • Managing the electronic IRM ﬁles in the Core Repository of Products (CROPP) • Distributing the electronic IRM ﬁles from the CROPP to other IRS divisions (
) IRM team members also participate on various task forces and groups sible for IRM process redesign and implementation. To see a current list of IRM team members, visit (

, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process, describes the IRM its components, including the • author and Internal Management Document (IMD) responsibilities • checklist for preparing IRMs for publishing • format • numbering • sample Manual Transmittals • structure (

) The letter program team performs publishing and customer analysis, and ministrative and operational workﬂow processes, for the public-use letters to communicate with the public about tax matters and to provide general information. Publishing formats letters based on M&P design standards. A system other than the product catalog page may generate the ﬁnal letter to the taxpayer and may format it differently. However, the textual content stay the same. Publishing does not format Correspondex letters but links to the SERP Numerical Index image of the letter posted online at serp.enterprise.irs.gov/databases/forms-ltrs-pubs.dr/crxltrs.dr/num.htm. ing posts the HTML source ﬁle to the CROPP. NOTE: Letters associated paper and/or online surveys are not considered systemically generated correspondence. (
) If an IRS letter is sent to
or more entities, then Publishing must assign official IRS letter and catalog number, and the Office of Taxpayer dence (OTC) must review the letter content. See IRM
, Item IDs, letter numbering standards and IRM
for Office of Taxpayer dence Services. (
) Publishing specialists number, format, design, issue, and post letters to Core Repository of Published Products (CROPP). (
) Refer to IRM
, Letters, at
for detailed information on the Letter program. Visit the Form Letter gram Intranet page at http://publish.no.irs.gov/pubsys/letterp/lphome.html the most current information. (

) An attachment to a letter asking the taxpayer to complete and return tion is a form and must be identiﬁed with form and catalog numbers. A separate Publishing Services Request (PSR) is required to create a new See IRM
, Forms, for form requirements. (

) Before submitting a request to create a new letter, please go to our Catalog Information page at http://publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html, and search by title to determine if a suitable letter already exists. Additionally, can view the letter list of all letter numbers, which includes active letters newly assigned letter numbers. Use the down arrows at the column to sort the ﬁle by originator name, originator address, long title, etc. (
) IRM

, Office of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, IRS dence Manual, provides guidance and procedures for the preparation of and Treasury correspondence. The consistent use of IRS letterhead will the IRS present one face to the public while reassuring taxpayers that spondence they receive from IRS is legitimate and official. (
) To accomplish this, IRS stationery is produced in two ways: • Preprinted stationery paper • Electronic letterhead (where approved by business unit) (
) For correspondence produced on preprinted stationery, the letterhead is printed using speciﬁc green ink on a particular type of paper that carries eagle watermark. (
) For electronically produced correspondence, it’s acceptable for the to print in black ink.

If an IRS letter is sent to 10 or more entities, then Publishing must assign an official IRS letter and catalog number, and the Office of Taxpayer Correspon- dence (OTC) must review the letter content. See IRM 1.17.10.3, Item IDs, for letter numbering standards and IRM 25.13.1 for Office of Taxpayer Correspon-
(11-19-2012) Letterhead/Stationery Program
and Programs
page (
) In both cases, you must use a customized font. We developed this font to make it difficult for external entities to forge IRS stationery. (
) To access the only acceptable stationery formats and their corresponding templates, go to http://publish.no.irs.gov/pubsys/letterhead/lttrhead.html. (
) You may order preprinted stationery from the IRS forms hotline at the Distribution Center (NDC). Call the NDC at

and provide the operator with the stationery’s catalog number and your Internal Management Documents Distribution Systems (IMDDS) order point number. If you don’t know your IMDDS order point number, check the IMDDS Order Point tion Page at http://publish.no.irs.gov/distsys/imdds/opnlkup.html. (

) Publishing and Distribution team members input and maintain course ments, printing and distribution of IRS training material. Team members also provide technical support in the areas of quantity requirements, copy tion, printing schedules, printing contracts, and printing budgets. (

) The training team supports official training courses developed by Learning Education (L&E) and supported through the Integrated Talent Management system (ITM). This includes the Training Products Distribution System products and Automated Data Processing (ADP) products used at IRS campuses. The training team also processes one-time publishing requests pilot materials used to develop subsequent ELMS courses. For additional mation, refer to Training Products Program at http://publish.no.irs.gov/pubsys/ training/training.html. (

RM
, Item IDs, regarding identiﬁcation standards for products. (

) The Substitute Form Program reviews and approves tax forms and reproduced by software developers and form designers, commonly known as substitute forms. The major responsibility of the program is to ensure the integrity of IRS forms is upheld, but to also ensure that the IRS, and other ernment agencies, will receive quality substitute forms that will have no adverse impact on processing. (

) Analysts provide information to vendors, in publications and through email, roles, responsibilities, procedures, resources, and any other information not speciﬁed in governing publications and or revenue procedures. Although the primary responsibility of the unit is to ensure the quality and integrity of duced IRS forms is upheld, analysts are also responsible for responding to correspondence received from internal and external stakeholders and vendors, certiﬁed public accountants (CPA), tax practitioners, and taxpayers. most cases, providing feedback requires extensive research and to ensure that vendors, practitioners, and taxpayers receive the most information to avoid an adverse impact when reproducing and or ﬁling substi- tute forms. In addition, analysts are also tasked with providing assistance information for investigations initiated by the agency (e.g., TIGTA or OCA). (

) Forms reviewed by the unit and covered in publications and revenue proce- dures include: • Applications for permission to ﬁle returns electronically and forms as required documentation for electronically ﬁled returns Internal Revenue Manual

) The Substitute Form Program reviews and approves tax forms and schedules reproduced by software developers and form designers, commonly known as substitute forms. The major responsibility of the program is to ensure the integrity of IRS forms is upheld, but to also ensure that the IRS, and other gov- ernment agencies, will receive quality substitute forms that will have no adverse impact on processing. (

) Analysts provide information to vendors, in publications and through email, on roles, responsibilities, procedures, resources, and any other information not speciﬁed in governing publications and or revenue procedures. Although the primary responsibility of the unit is to ensure the quality and integrity of repro- duced IRS forms is upheld, analysts are also responsible for responding to correspondence received from internal and external stakeholders and partners, vendors, certiﬁed public accountants (CPA), tax practitioners, and taxpayers. In most cases, providing feedback requires extensive research and collaboration to ensure that vendors, practitioners, and taxpayers receive the most accurate information to avoid an adverse impact when reproducing and or ﬁling substi- tute forms. In addition, analysts are also tasked with providing assistance and information for investigations initiated by the agency (e.g., TIGTA or OCA). (

) Forms reviewed by the unit and covered in publications and revenue proce- dures include: • Applications for permission to ﬁle returns electronically and forms used as required documentation for electronically ﬁled returns

roles, responsibilities, procedures, resources, and any other information not speciﬁed in governing publications and or revenue procedures. In addition, analysts are also tasked with providing assistance and information for investigations initiated by the agency (e.g., TIGTA or OCA).

The survey program team is responsible for working closely IRS

wide with Business Operating Division representatives (BODs) to coordinate the and administration of their Customer Experience Research surveys (CER) Burden surveys. The CER surveys evaluate customer experiences with their interaction with the IRS and help to identify operational improvements. The Burden surveys provide Congress and the President with accurate estimates the time and money taxpayers spend to follow federal tax rules and regula

tions. Tax Administrators and policy managers use this information to reduce and manage taxpayer burden. Survey Program Specialists are responsible for assisting the BOD with preparing their correspondence pieces for production and mailing by working closely with the Office of Taxpayer Correspondence to ensure the content complies with IRS requirements and the Letter Program to ensure that letters are formatted according to IRS standards. The Program Specialists also work closely with the Human Capital Office (HCO) Personnel Security (PS) Contractor Security Onboarding to ensure print contractors have the necessary clearances to work with Personally ﬁable Information (PII) and Sensitive but Unclassiﬁed Information (SBU). This process involves ﬁngerprinting, background checks, credit checks, selective service enrollment and tax compliancy. Only after they receive clearance can contractor work on IRS work involving PII and/or SBU. The Specialist must ensure that each print contractor is up to date with their annual mandatory brieﬁngs and that their training is recorded in the Talent Management (ITM) system.
Systems and Programs 1.17.2
Program Planning Conferences follow review and evaluation conferences. The primary areas discussed during program planning are:

Both applications provide data to support product procurement scheduling tracking, cost and quantity information, billing and payment information, product revision information, distribution warehousing and order fulﬁllment tivities, balanced measures, and customer-oriented applications (e.g., Electronic Publishing website, milestone reporting, ﬁnancial reporting, and customer satisfaction survey). (

) The Electronic Status Notice (ESN) system provides the official record for forms, letters, notices, publications, envelopes, documents, and training cations. ESN is the database of all published products. (

) The purpose of ESN is to collect, verify, and disseminate information about IRS published products. This information consists of various physical, cal, and program-oriented data. Its data structure is a product attribute ﬁle used to identify the use and handling of published products. ESN is the tive source of all product-related characteristics and must contain all the information required by the other Publishing data systems and applications. (e.g., PSD, ELITE, CROPP, etc.) (

) ESN contains information on published products, including identifying title, using and stocking points, related directives, disposition of prior issuances, and other data pertaining to their purpose and use. (

) ESN also contains information on those standard forms most commonly in Internal Revenue Service offices and those forms and publications of agencies and bureaus, such as Department of the Treasury, Office of Personnel Management and Social Security Administration, whose forms publications are used in the regular course of IRS business. (
) No other published product database will be maintained within the IRS the expressed written permission of the Director, M&P Publishing. (
) The Publishing Services Data (PSD) application provides budget execution management, requisition tracking and control, and GPO processing for all requests for publishing services. (

) M&P uses PSD to: • Record, report, and verify ﬁnancial obligations and GPO Intergovern- mental Payment and Collections invoices made for procurements of products • Maintain the system of record audit ﬁnancial documentation for GPO procurements • Maintain procurement data used to generate various procurement documents such as GPO Form

and Distribution ﬁles • Provide data for product and procurement analysis • Provide accurate production status information to customers and holders • Provide data for Publishing’s balanced measures results

Both applications provide data to support product procurement scheduling tracking, cost and quantity information, billing and payment information, product revision information, distribution warehousing and order fulﬁllment ac- tivities, balanced measures, and customer-oriented applications (e.g., Electronic Publishing website, milestone reporting, ﬁnancial reporting, and customer satisfaction survey).
No other published product database will be maintained within the IRS without the expressed written permission of the Director, M&P Publishing.

) M&P Publishing develops and maintains a publishing management system collect, store, manage, and deliver electronic products for use in electronic publishing applications such as web publishing (intranet and internet), on- demand printing, and CD-ROM and DVD publishing. Publishing specialists the ﬁrst point of contact for adding, revising, or obsoleting products in the Repository of Published Products (CROPP). Only Publishing can post published products to the intranet and IRS.gov. (

) The CROPP contains all number-controlled, official published products by the Service and must serve as the primary source for all products that this criteria. These products are available (for download or print) to IRS employees through the Publishing and Distribution Intranet site at http:// publish.no.irs.gov, or may be hyperlinked from other Service Intranet using standardized Common Gateway Interface (CGI) programs. (

) The CROPP contains ﬁles of all official IRS forms, instructions, documents, publications, manuals, and other Service products in standard, formats. Certain products are available for local printing by the National bution Center (NDC). (
) M&P Publishing established the CROPP to manage product attributes and make available appropriate ﬁle formats for use in electronic and print tions. (
) At http://publish.no.irs.gov/ephlp.html#tab=tab
, the CROPP contains tions of the following types of electronic ﬁles: • Source-ﬁle formats [Standard Generalized Markup Language Extensible Markup Language (XML), Encapsulated Pos
cript and Portable Document Format (PDF)] • Distribution ﬁles [Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) and Portable Document Format (PDF)] • Graphic ﬁles and text ﬁles (various formats) (
) Electronic ﬁles can only post to the CROPP after the product content ″ ″ originator provides an ok-to-publish. (
) The CROPP can be accessed at http://publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html. (

) M&P Publishing develops and maintains a centralized composition system store, manage, and transform electronic products from a single-source ﬁle output ﬁles used for print or viewing electronically. Source ﬁles are added the system via the Composition Process Management (CPM) application. Source ﬁles include the following types: • Encapsulated Pos
cript (EPS) • Extensible Markup Language (XML) • Portable Document Format (PDF) • Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML) (

) Publishing uses XML transformation software to transform the source ﬁle(s) into multiple output ﬁle types used for print or electronic displays such as Internet Explorer, Adobe Reader, Tablets, or Smart Phones. Output ﬁles include the following types: •
ook ﬁle format (
ub) Internal Revenue Manual

) All output ﬁles are stored in the CPM application and select ﬁle types are also incorporated into the CROPP, where they are accessible via the IRS Intranet. (
) You should send requests for

ook products that need to be produced outside of the Integrated Composition Program to the Publishing Services branch of Publishing using the Publishing Services Request (PSR) application. Publishing will facilitate the creation and distribution of these products. (
) Access to the CPM application is restricted to M&P Publishing employees, who can access it at http://publish.no.irs.gov/publish/pub-elc.html. (
) Access the PSR application at http://caps-as.enterprise.irs.gov/psr/app.
All output ﬁles are stored in the CPM application and select ﬁle types are also incorporated into the CROPP, where they are accessible via the IRS Intranet.

You should send requests for eBook products that need to be produced outside of the Integrated Composition Program to the Publishing Services branch of Publishing using the Publishing Services Request (PSR) application. Publishing will facilitate the creation and distribution of these products.
